Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Xerox Business Services, LLC, now called Conduent Business Services, for software errors that led to incorrect consumer information about more than one million borrowers being sent to credit reporting agencies. The agency also accused the company of failing to notify all of its auto lender clients about known flaws in its software that led to the errors. The  consent order required Xerox to pay a $1.1 million civil penalty, explain its mistakes to its lender clients, and fix its faulty software.

Private Litigation Case Title: Bell et al v. Affiliated Computer Services, Inc et al
Simeon v. Affiliated Computer Services, Inc et al

Description: The Bureau found that the company engaged in unfair practices that violated the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 by failing to adjust in a timely manner principal balances of student loans made under the Federal Family Education Loan Program.
ACS Eduction Services agreed to pay $2.4 million in settlement of allegations it failed to properly process federal repayment plans for student loans and engaged in harassing debt collection.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Federal student loan servicer ACS Education Services, currently known as Conduent Education Services, agreed to pay $9 million to settle allegations that it steered distressed borrowers away from available income-based repayment plans towards other, more expensive options, thus costing them money and increasing their risk of default.

Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Agency: Arizona Department of Insurance and Financial Institutions
Notes: This case was brought by the Arizona Department of Financial Institutions before it merged with the Department of Insurance.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Conduent Education Services LLC, fka Xerox Education Services LLC, dba ACS Education Services LLC (CES), a contractor that serviced student loans for lenders under the Federal Family Education Loan Program (FFEL), agreed to pay $7.9 million to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by submitting or causing the submission of false claims to the Department of Education.
